Catalytic hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF) is an important reaction for biomass valorization. We report that metal oxides (including MgO, ZnO, SiO2 and TiO2) supported Pt catalysts show vastly different BHMF selectivity towards the hydrogenation of HMF. The basic metal oxide MgO supported Pt catalyst affords 99 % selectivity of BHMF, while the typical acidic metal oxide TiO2 supported Pt catalyst displays only 28 % selectivity of BHMF. HMF chemisorption on these catalysts show that the basic sites of metal oxide bonding to the CO group of HMF promote the BHMF selectivity, while the acidic sites of metal oxide favor the adsorption of CC group of HMF, which decreases the BHMF selectivity. It is proposed that the cooperation between basic sites and Pt atoms (activating H2) boosted the BHMF selectivity. Comprehensive studies including reactivity, recyclability, stability, solvent effect on the Pt/MgO catalyst were also carried out. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Metal oxide Basicity Acidity 5-hydroxymethylfurfural Hydrogenation 1 Introduction The transformation of platform chemical 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is one of the important reactions in biorefinery [1–3]. HMF contains unsaturated groups of CC, CO, and a furan ring, making it feasible to be converted to biofuels, polymeric monomers and value-added chemicals through catalytic reduction processes like hydrogenation, amination, and ring opening [4–6]. For instance, 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF) produced by selective reduction of HMF has been of great research interests in recent years [7–19] due to its potential application in the synthesis of functionalized polyethers, furanic polyamides and polyurethanes, also in the synthesis of pharmaceutical precursor of multi-hetero macrocycles [6]. Selective reduction of the CO bond of HMF to alcohol simultaneously without further hydrogenation of hydroxyl group and CC bond is the key to obtain a high selectivity of BHMF. To guarantee this, it is essential to develop selective catalysts. A binuclear ruthenium complex (Shvo’s catalyst) showed 99 % yield of BHMF towards the selective hydrogenation of HMF, and the hydroxyl group of HMF was critical for the formation of intermediate from HMF to BHMF [20]. However, the high cost and poor recyclability of the homogeneous Ru catalyst limited its further industrial application, while heterogeneous metal catalysts can circumvent these limitations. Apart from the metal properties like particle size and coordination environment [9,10,14,15,19,21–23], the nature of the support of heterogenous catalysts played a crucial role in the selective hydrogenation of HMF into BHMF. For instance, Ir/C displayed 69.7 % selectivity of BHMF, whereas Ir/TiO2 afforded 95.4 % selectivity, which was attributed to the activation of the CO group of HMF by the defect sites of Ti3+ or oxygen vacancies on TiO2 support during the hydrogenation reaction [12]. Wang et al. prepared a series of Pt catalysts supported on carbon materials and found the BHMF selectivities are dependent on the functional groups on the surface of carbon material [24]. Ohyama et al. reported that when gold was anchored on basic metal oxide supports such as Al2O3, the corresponding catalyst achieved 96 % selectivity of BHMF towards the hydrogenation of HMF, while those on acidic supports like TiO2 and ZrO2 facilitated ring-opening reaction of HMF [19]. Bell et al. also found Pt/Al2O3 (with 5 wt% Pt loading) was a good catalyst for selective hydrogenation of HMF to BHMF with a yield of 82 % [25]. Zhu et al. reported that moderate surface acidity of ZnO contributed to 99.1 % selectivity of BHMF over the Cu/ZnO catalyst [11]. Besides, the acidic sites on the surface of mesoporous Al2O3 boosted the BHMF selectivity [26]. It seems contradictory about the basicity or acidity of metal oxide supports being the primary factor for BHMF selectivity, and comprehensive investigations on the basicity and acidity of metal oxide support have barely been performed over metal oxide supported metal catalysts for catalytic hydrogenation of HMF into BHMF. We herein investigate the catalytic hydrogenation of HMF to BHMF over Pt catalysts supported on metal oxide of MgO, ZnO, SiO2 and TiO2. The Pt/MgO catalyst with basic metal oxide as support afford 99 % selectivity of BHMF, while Pt/TiO2 with acidic metal oxide as support shows 28 % selectivity of BHMF with the major product being acetals formed by the reaction of aldehyde of HMF with alcoholic solvent. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) of HMF chemisorption on these supported Pt catalysts reveal that the basic sites of metal oxide favor the coordination with the CO group of HMF, consequently boosting the BHMF selectivity; while the acidic sites of metal oxide prefer the adsorption of the CC group of HMF, which endows a flat adsorption of HMF on the surface of catalyst and subsequently both the carbonyl and the hydroxyl of HMF are available for reduction, thus resulting in low BHMF selectivity. By replacing the precious metal anchored on MgO support with gold, ruthenium and iridium, all the corresponding catalyst afford over 98 % selectivity of BHMF. This implies that the metal species only activates H2, and the basic sites of metal oxide coordinate to the CO group of HMF, together contributing to the exceptional BHMF selectivity. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Supported Pt catalysts were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method. Typically, to a stirring aqueous solution of H2PtCl6, metal oxide (1.0 g) was added and kept stirring for 12 h. The mixture was then dried at 80 ℃, the resulting solid was ground and heated in air at 350 °C for 3 h to afford supported Pt catalysts. Metal oxide supports including MgO (Kemerl, 12.4 m2/g), SiO2 (Alfa Aesar, 5 m2/g), TiO2 (P25, Evonik, 50 m2/g), ZnO (Acros Organics, 4.3 m2/g) are commercially purchased without further treatment. Ultrapure water was used. The Pt loading was controlled at ca. 0.1 wt%. The synthesis of 2 %Pt/MgO, 1 %Pt/MgO, 0.5 %Pt/MgO was similar to that of Pt/MgO only with different Pt loadings. The synthesis of Au/MgO, Ir/MgO and Ru/MgO was also similar to that of Pt/MgO by using different metal precursors: HAuCl4, IrCl3 and RuCl3. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The loading amounts of Pt were detected by the inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) on a Shimadzu ICP-OES 7300DV instrument. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was recorded on a PANanlytical X′pert-Pro diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation in the range of 5°− 80° using a step size of 0.33 degrees. The BET surface area and average pore size distribution of the samples were characterized from the N2 physical adsorption–desorption isotherms obtained at minus 196 °C with a Micrometric ASAP 2020 HD88 automated system. Before the adsorption measurement, the samples were evacuated at 200 °C for 2 h. The specific surface areas were determined by the BET method. The pore volumes and pore sizes were determined by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda procedure. CO2 and NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) measurements were carried out using Micromeritics Autochem 2910. Before adsorption, each sample (100 mg) was placed in a U-shaped quartz reactor and heated to 350 ℃ for 1 h with flowing O2/He (5 v/v %, 10 cm3/min), and then cooled down to 50 ℃ for CO2-TPD and 100 ℃ for NH3-TPD. The sample was exposed to CO2 or NH3 for 0.5 h and was maintained in a He flow for 0.5 h to remove physiosorbed CO2 or NH3. Afterwards, the temperature was increased linearly at a rate of 10 ℃/min to 900 ℃ for recording the signal of CO2 or NH3. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted using Thermo Fisher Excalab X + . All binding energies were calibrated by taking the carbon 1 s peak as a reference (284.8 eV). Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) of CO chemisorption was conducted on a Bruker VERTEX 70 FT-IR spectrometer with a homemade cell. The catalyst was firstly blown with helium gas (30 mL/min) for 0.5 h, following with a collection of the background spectra. CO gas was introduced into the reaction cell until CO adsorption peak intensity does not increase anymore. Then the physical CO adsorption was completely removed by sweeping helium gas, followed by the recording of the IR spectra. DRIFTS of HMF chemisorption was performed with similar procedure, except that HMF gas was swept into the cell by heating HMF to 130 ℃. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted using METTLER TOLEDO. Sample was kept at 100 ℃ for 0.5 h and was increased from 100 ℃ to 750 ℃ with a heating rate of 10 ℃/min in an air atmosphere. 2.3 Catalytic testing Hydrogenation of HMF was performed in a stainless-steel autoclave (25 mL) equipped with a pressure gauge and magnetic stirrer (Beijing Shiji Senlang Experimental Instrument Co Ltd). Before the reaction, a mixture of HMF, catalyst, isopropanol (10 mL), dodecane (internal standard) was placed in a quartz vessel. After being sealed, the autoclave was purged with hydrogen gas (99.99 %) at least three times to ensure that the system is air-free, and then was charged with 2 MPa hydrogen. The stirring speed was set to be 1000 r/min. The reaction time commenced after reaching the set temperature. After the reaction was completed, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, followed with the discharge of the remaining hydrogen gas. The resulting products were condensed, and then were analyzed by Agilent GC-MS and GC (7890B) equipped with DB-35MS capillary column. The selectivity to each product was calculated by the following expression Si = Ni/∑Np, where Ni is the molar number of the product ‘i′ and ∑Np is the total molar number of the products. Conversion was determined by (1-Nb/Na), where Nb is the molar number of HMF before reaction, Na is the molar number of HMF after reaction. Carbon mass balances were controlled at ∼95 %. Turn of frequency (TOF) was calculated by moles of reactant converted divided by the moles of Pt element and the reaction time (hour). ( Scheme 1). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical characterizations XRD patterns of as-synthesized metal oxide (including MgO, ZnO, SiO2 and TiO2) supported Pt catalysts are shown in Fig. S1. All the samples exhibited characteristic peaks corresponding to the metal oxide by comparing with their standard diffraction peaks. No peaks for Pt species were detected, likely due to its low loadings (0.1 wt%). And no clear Pt particles were observed on Pt/MgO by microscopic measurements (Fig. S2). Specific surface area and pore-size distribution of all the samples were studied by the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. S3). As listed in Table 1, among these Pt catalysts, the Pt/MgO catalyst possesses the highest surface area (139.0 m2/g) and pore volume (0.44 cm3/g), which are greatly improved in comparison to that (65.3 m2/g and 0.19 cm3/g) of MgO, indicating the surface structures of MgO in Pt/MgO was modified by the introduction of Pt. Temperature-Programmed Desorption (TPD) of CO2 and NH3 were used to investigate the concentration of basic and acidic sites of the supported Pt catalysts, the results are listed in Table 1. For the CO2-TPD profiles ( Fig. 1a), all the samples showed strong desorption peaks in the region of 350–600 °C, which can be assigned to the strong basic sites. Pt/MgO and Pt/TiO2 displayed desorption peaks from 100 to 350 °C, which can be assigned to the weak basic sites. It is suggested that the high temperature peak is attributed to the strong Lewis base of low-coordinated surface sites and/or defect sites, and the weak basic sites are mainly associated with the surface hydroxyl groups [27–29]. One can see that all the Pt catalysts consist of strong basic sites. The total amounts of basic sites of Pt/MgO (43.4 μmol/g) are much higher than the other three catalysts with similar amounts of basic sites about 6.0 μmol/g. Significantly, when comparing the profiles of MgO and Pt/MgO, the decline intensity of the peak from 350 °C to 550 °C was more obvious than that of other peaks, suggesting the defect sites on the surface of MgO were occupied by Pt atoms [28,29]. For the NH3-TPD profiles (Fig. 1b), Pt/TiO2 showed a strong broad desorption peak from 150 to 500 °C with total acidic sites of 29.3 μmol/g, indicating its strong acidic property, whereas very weak desorption peaks were observed in the profiles of Pt/MgO, Pt/ZnO and Pt/SiO2, indicative of their weak acidic property. By comparing the ratio of the total amount of basic sites and the total amount of acidic sites in these Pt catalysts, it follows the order of Pt/MgO (6.8) > Pt/ZnO (1.2) > Pt/SiO2 (0.79) > Pt/TiO2 (0.22) (Table 1), which means Pt/MgO possesses the strongest basic property and Pt/TiO2 has the strongest acidic property among these metal-oxide supported Pt catalysts. 3.2 Catalytic activities The catalytic performance of these Pt catalysts was investigated on the hydrogenation of HMF at 120 °C with isopropanol as the solvent ( Table 2). Under the same reaction conditions, Pt/MgO displayed a superior catalytic performance with a selectivity of 99 % for the major product BHMF and 1 % selectivity for the side product 5-methylfurfural (MF) at a conversion of 84 % (entry 1). As to Pt/ZnO, it displayed a competitive BHMF selectivity of 97 % with a lower conversion of 25 %, but small number of acetals (2 %) was detected as solvent product (SP) by the reaction of HMF with isopropanol (entry 2). The BHMF selectivity lowered to 90 % over the Pt/SiO2 catalyst with 9 % of the unwanted product SP (entry 3). The SP selectivity surged to 62 % when using Pt/TiO2 as the catalyst, with 28 % selectivity of BHMF and 10 % selectivity of MF (entry 4). We notice that the BHMF selectivity over these Pt catalysts follows this order: Pt/MgO > Pt/ZnO > Pt/SiO2 > Pt/TiO2, as shown in Fig. 2, which is in line with their ratio of basic sites to acidic sites. This suggests that the BHMF selectivities strongly correlate with the basic and acidic properties of these Pt catalysts. The 99 % selectivity of BHMF over Pt/MgO is likely due to the strongest basic property with the ratio of basic sites to acidic sites of 6.8. The Pt/TiO2 catalyst with strongest acidic property displayed very different catalytic performance from Pt/MgO, with 28 % selectivity of BHMF and 10 % selectivity of MF, and the major product being SP. Acetalization of aldehydes in alcoholic solvents commonly occurred in acid-catalyzed reaction [30–35]. As to Pt/ZnO and Pt/SiO2, the number of basic sites and acidic sites is very close, which makes the basic property relatively less strong, thus resulting in decreased BHMF selectivities (97 % and 90 % respectively). Meanwhile, the relatively stronger acidic property of Pt/ZnO and Pt/SiO2 than Pt/MgO promoted the acetalization reaction. 3.3 Proposed reaction mechanism To further understand the acid or base catalyzed hydrogenation of HMF over the supported Pt catalysts, DRIFTS of HMF chemisorption was carried out. After HMF molecule is adsorbed on the active sites of a heterogenous catalyst, the functional group of CO, CC or hydroxyl forms chemical interactions with the active sites ( Scheme 2), followed by selective hydrogenation of the functional group. As shown in Fig. 3a, the infrared spectroscopy of HMF molecule showed a stretching band at 1670 cm−1 and a band at 1523 cm−1 corresponding to the CO group and the CC group of HMF respectively [7]. It is difficult to analyze the hydroxyl group of HMF, due to the overlapped adsorption peaks of water and the hydroxyl group. Obvious redshifts of CO stretching and CC stretching were observed when HMF is adsorbed on the Pt catalysts by comparing with that of HMF, indicating a successful chemisorption. Moreover, the degree of downshift was different; taking Pt/MgO and Pt/TiO2 as examples, it is smaller for Pt/MgO than Pt/TiO2, indicating CO stretching and CC stretching of HMF is much stronger on Pt/MgO. This means the chemical interactions between the HMF molecules and the active sites on Pt/TiO2 are stronger than that on Pt/MgO, as a result, the desorption of the hydrogenated HMF molecule would cost more energy on Pt/TiO2 than on Pt/MgO. This might explain the high activity of Pt/MgO than Pt/TiO2 under the same reaction conditions. Notably, the ratio (R) of the intensity between the ν(CO) and the ν(CC) varies (Fig. 3a). By comparing the peak area between the ν(CO) and the ν(CC), the results are shown in Fig. 3b and Table S1, one can foresee the adsorption mode of HMF on the Pt catalysts. R for HMF molecule is 2.86, and it is 6.46 after HMF adsorbed on Pt/ZnO and 12.5 on Pt/MgO, suggesting the numbers of the carbonyl group of HMF coordinates to the basic sites are improving, as a result, the BHMF selectivity rises. We thus propose that the majority of carbonyl group of HMF bonds to the low-coordinated surface sites on supports [27,29,36], because no weak basic sites on the surface of Pt/ZnO. R declines to 1.93 on Pt/TiO2, less than 2.86 of HMF, suggesting the adsorption mode of HMF altered compared with that on Pt/MgO, thus resulting in a dramatic change in the selectivity. We infer that a stronger adsorption of the CC group makes HMF molecules lying flat on the surface of the Pt/TiO2 catalyst (Scheme 2), thus hydrogenation would proceed on both the carbonyl and the hydroxyl group of HMF. Overall, the selective hydrogenation of HMF is primarily dependent on the acidic and basic property of the supported Pt catalysts. Moreover, both MgO and TiO2 show chemical adsorption of HMF molecule (Fig. S4 and S5), suggesting the active sites for HMF adsorption are on the skeleton of the support. By comparing R on the typical basic support MgO (6.22) and acidic support TiO2 (0.60) (Fig. 3b), we infer that the active sites of basic support favor the chemisorption of the carbonyl group and the acidic support prefer the chemisorption of the CC group of HMF. When using MgO support as catalyst (Table 2, entry 6), catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) [37] of HMF with isopropanol as hydrogen source displayed 97 % BHMF selectivity at a conversion of 16 %, while under identical reaction conditions, Pt/MgO showed 84 % conversion. This means that the efficiency of CTH is much lower than that of catalytic hydrogenation. On the other hand, it suggests the presence of Pt only promoted the conversion by activation of H2, which had no significant impact on the selectivity of BHMF. In order to investigate the impacts of Pt species, we prepared Pt/MgO catalysts with Pt loadings of 0.5 wt%, 1.0 wt% and 2.0 wt% by similar preparation procedures. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) of CO chemisorption were used to compare their electronic structures. As shown in Fig. S6, different CO adsorption peaks were observed, indicative of variations in the electronic structures of the Pt species. Under identical reaction conditions (with same molar ratio of HMF to Pt), these catalysts showed similar selectivity of BHMF above 98 % ( Table 3), indicating the variation in electronic structure of Pt species had no big influence on the selectivity. We also prepared Ir/MgO, Ru/MgO and Au/MgO with 0.1 wt% metal loadings using similar preparation method with Pt/MgO. Under identical reaction conditions, these MgO-supported meal catalysts all showed > 98 % selectivity of BHMF with different conversions, suggesting the type of metals had no significant impact on the selectivity of BHMF. We might conclude that the metal in the MgO supported metal catalysts played a trivial role in the control of BHMF selectivity in the hydrogenation of HMF, only affected the activity of the hydrogenation reaction. Besides, we studied the role of Pt species in Pt/TiO2. Pt/TiO2-H200 was prepared by treatment of Pt/TiO2 in hydrogen atmosphere at 200 °C. The variation in Pt electronic structures was confirmed by DRIFT of CO chemisorption (Fig. S7). Under identical reaction conditions, they showed similar selectivity of BHMF (Fig. S8), suggesting the variation in the Pt electronic structures had no big impact on the selectivity. Combining the above experimental results, we propose that the property of support was critical to the selectivity of BHMF in the hydrogenation of HMF over oxide supported metal catalysts, the role of metal was to activate H2. The cooperation between the basic sites for adsorption of HMF via the carbonyl group and the Pt atoms for H2 activation in Pt/MgO boosted the BHMF selectivity. 3.4 Further studies on the Pt/MgO catalyst Due to the excellent catalytic performance of Pt/MgO, further investigations were conducted. When the reaction temperature was raised to 150 °C, it displayed 99 % selectivity of BHMF at a conversion of 99 % (Table 2, entry 5). We then performed BHMF hydrogenation reaction using the Pt/MgO catalyst at 120 °C ( Fig. 4), no reaction occurred. Whereas MF hydrogenation reaction using the Pt/MgO catalyst under identical reaction conditions displayed 99 % selectivity of 5-methylfurfuryl alcohol and 100 % conversion. These results indicate the Pt/MgO catalyst barely reduce the alcohol group but can smoothly reduce carbonyl group in the testing reaction under specific reaction conditions. Studies of solvent effects showed isopropanol was the best among the alcoholic solvents (Fig. S9). It was reported that water can significantly influence catalytic performance on hydrogenation reactions [14,38,39]. By adding water into the isopropanol solvent, the reaction activity greatly decreased (Fig. S10). This means water plays a negative role for the activity and selectivity in hydrogenation of HMF over the Pt/MgO catalyst. The recyclability of the Pt/MgO catalyst on the hydrogenation of HMF was tested under 120 °C for 1 h. As shown in Fig. 5a, the BHMF selectivity kept at 99 % after the 3rd run, however, the conversion dropped from 84 % to 29 %. Regeneration of the catalyst was carried out at 350 °C for 3 h and the weight of catalyst dropped from 100 mg to 53 mg after the regeneration. The regenerated catalyst was applied to the reaction for the fourth run, gratifyingly, the catalytic activity in terms of TOF were completely recovered and surpassed the activity of the first run. Besides, we noted that the Pt/MgO catalyst slowly lost its activity along with time, but remained 99 % selectivity of BHMF (Fig. 5b). After stored in air for one month, the catalyst lost its 60 % activity. However, after calcination in air at 350 °C, the catalyst can completely regain the activity without any decrease in selectivity. We found the surface area decreased from 139 m2/g to 94 m2/g after 1 month storage (Table 1). The weight loss behavior was studied by TGA. The catalyst stored in air for one month underwent an obvious weight loss from 100 to 350 °C and lost 5.0 % mass weight at 750 °C in total, while the fresh sample only lost 3.5 % mass weight in total (Fig. S11), strongly suggesting the active sites of the catalyst were covered by H2O and CO2 when stored in air, thus resulting in a decreased activity. This is in agreement with the characteristic of MgO [28]. In order to see the impacts of pretreatment in hydrogen atmosphere on the catalytic performance, Pt/MgO was reduced in hydrogen atmosphere at 200 °C for 2 h, affording Pt/MgO-H200. Under the reaction condition, Pt/MgO-H200 displayed identical selectivity to Pt/MgO, but slightly lower conversion, as shown in Fig. S12. Pt 4 f XPS spectra overlapped with the spectra of Mg loss, no useful information can be obtained. CO-DRIFT on Pt/MgO and Pt/MgO-H200 showed almost identical CO chemisorption peaks, as shown in Fig. S13, indicating their similar Pt electronic structures, on the other hand, it means the treatment in hydrogen had no big impact on Pt species. O1s XPS spectra showed that the total amount of absorbed water and hydroxyl group on MgO reduced by 7 % after treatment in hydrogen at 200 °C (Fig. S14). These results indicate that the basic sites on MgO were the active sites for the adsorption of the carbonyl group of HMF, treatment in hydrogen slightly reduced the active sites for the activation of HMF, because of their almost identical Pt species, thus the activity decreased. The influence of reaction time on the product distributions for HMF hydrogenation was then studied. The reaction was carried out using 600 mg catalyst at 90 °C and the quantity of HMF was increased by ten times. As shown in Fig. 6, it took 350 h to reach a complete conversion of HMF. The BHMF selectivity basically kept at 99 %, and MF selectivity was less than 1 %. After 50 h reaction, trace amount of furfural alcohol, 5-methylfurfural alcohol and solvent product were detected by GC-MS. The carbon balance gradually decreased to 78 % after 350 h′ reaction. The catalyst became brownish after the reaction was completed, as shown in Fig. S15, which was also observed during the cyclability studies, indicating the formation of coking during the reaction. It was then calcinated in air at 350 °C for 3 h, with the brownish color being completely removed. The ICP results showed an increase in the Pt loading after the calcination (Table S2), suggesting it was the leaching of MgO support that reduced the weight of catalyst. A fixed bed reactor might be able to circumvent the leaching problem of MgO [28]. In short, the Pt/MgO catalyst is a selective catalyst with acceptable recyclability and stability due to the low cost of MgO, together with the low loadings of metal, it is thus of potential to be used in large scale manufacture for producing BHMF from hydrogenation of HMF. 4 Conclusion In summary, we studied the basic and acidic properties of the Pt catalysts supported on MgO, ZnO, SiO2, TiO2 and the impacts on selective hydrogenation of HMF. Pt/MgO with largest amounts of basic sites shows 99 % selectivity of BHMF, whereas Pt/TiO2 with strongest acidic property displays inferior selectivity of BHMF. By using DRIFTS of HMF chemisorption on the supported Pt catalysts, we find that the ratio of peak intensity between CO stretching and CC stretching of HMF reflects the adsorption modes of HMF on the catalyst, which determines the selectivity of the catalytic hydrogenation of HMF. The ratio is 12.5 for Pt/MgO, much higher than 2.86 of HMF, which means the Pt/MgO catalyst dominantly bonds to CO group of HMF, thus affording a superior BHMF selectivity. Experimental results show the cooperation of the basic sites and metal atoms boosts the highly selective hydrogenation of HMF, in which basic sites are in charge of adsorption of carbonyl group of HMF and metal atoms activate H2. While, the ratio is 1.93 for Pt/TiO2, lower than 2.86 of HMF, indicating the Pt/TiO2 catalyst tends to the adsorb the CC group of HMF, which makes both carbonyl group and hydroxyl group of HMF available for hydrogenation. Studies on the selectivity, recyclability and stability of Pt/MgO indicate it is a promising industrial catalyst for catalytic hydrogenation of HMF to BHMF. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF) is an important reaction for biomass valorization. We report that metal oxides (including MgO, ZnO, SiO2 and TiO2) supported Pt catalysts show vastly different BHMF selectivity towards the hydrogenation of HMF. The basic metal oxide MgO supported Pt catalyst affords 99 % selectivity of BHMF, while the typical acidic metal oxide TiO2 supported Pt catalyst displays only 28 % selectivity of BHMF. HMF chemisorption on these catalysts show that the basic sites of metal oxide bonding to the CO group of HMF promote the BHMF selectivity, while the acidic sites of metal oxide favor the adsorption of CC group of HMF, which decreases the BHMF selectivity. It is proposed that the cooperation between basic sites and Pt atoms (activating H2) boosted the BHMF selectivity. Comprehensive studies including reactivity, recyclability, stability, solvent effect on the Pt/MgO catalyst were also carried out.
coredata.dc:title: Highly selective hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan over metal-oxide supported Pt catalysts: The role of basic sites
